repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: I can't find any other uses of `scanf`/`sscanf` or similar in Cython, which makes me think we might be deliberately avoiding them. But it does seem the simplest solution here.
.. and then the error message change below should be reverted

I agree with the general principle (just compare the strings). `Py_GetVersion()` will have spaces and possibly letters immediately after the version number so I think it needed a bit of selective copying to just pick out the version number though (so I haven't used quite this code)
Is `rtversion[5]` correct with `0 <= i < 4`? Since you seem to be using it straight in snprintf() below, I think you need to at least append a `\0`, no?
`rtversion[5] = {'\0'};` zero initializes the whole thing I believe (you only need to specify the first zero) so it should be fine
Do we actually need to do this copying at all? Why have two loops if one would do? I guess you were initially (aiming for) using `strncmp()` instead of the second loop?
"x also y" ? Fails to parse in my head. What were you saying here?
I think we need the copied version if we generate the exception message. But maybe we should leave the copy until then? I'll rewrite it like that...
I think this is something that I added for debugging something and accidentally left in - I'll remove it.

commit.message: Fix version detection and warning with double-digit versions
